data.text: Using a Smart Watch Mounted on Handlebars for Long-Distance Navigation

Hi there, does anyone use a smart watch like Garmin Fenix, etc. for navigation on their trips? The watch could be mounted on the handlebar instead of the wrist - example photo attached - but I'm not sure about the usability... I need navigation for long-distance running & hiking as well as bikepacking, but don't have the money to buy a watch AND a bike computer. I was wondering if anyone uses the watch like this. Any inputs & info appreciated! Thanks
Buy a powerbank and use a free app in the phone you already have. Works like a charm :-)
data.author: Hauke Kottek

data.text: I used to have one on my motorcycle. Left it out and the ice destroyed it.
data.author: George Muirhead

data.text: Hi, this is a universal watch mount. Its used to stick the watch to the handlebar. It is made out of rubber so its pretty stable. It costs a few bucks at decathlon or your LBS
data.author: Mehdi Mersni

data.text: I've been going through this scenario in my, too. I want navigation and a cool watch, but I know I'll only use like 1/100 th of the features. I'm most likely going to go the quad lock and iPhone route with power bank.
data.author: Mark Gingrass

data.text: Tough to see if you need to zoom out. I found even the Garmin 820 too small, but that is for trail networks.
data.author: Bob Bergen

data.text: I used my fenix5s like that for few seasons. Worked great üòâ

data.text: Yes, it works. Fenix 3 on my MTB bike. But with original garmin holder (big rubber). It is pretty stable. Hard to see map details but if you havent money like I do, it's option.
data.author: Irakli Chargeishvili

data.text: Chris Burkard, a well known photographer/bikepacker traversed Iceland with his Sunnto watch I believe. What apps or widgets it needs i'm curious about. I tried Komoot once but disliked it very much.
data.author: Dieter Geeraerts

data.text: Garmin makes an attachment that allows you to clip your watch on
data.author: Daniel Caskie

data.text: I used my laptop and it worked wonderfully.
data.author: Tuan Truong

data.text: I just use my phone and apps like RideWithGps. If I bring my watch it feels too much like training for races. I am touring to take a break! That setup looks pretty awesome though, love it!
data.author: David Miller

data.text: battery will run out in a day, suggest looking at solar powered bike computers instead, eg Trimm

data.text: I have a solar powered garmin watch, love it
data.author: Jay Jaynes

data.text: I use my Fenix all the time on my bike (but not for nav) - but get one of these though makes a big differece mounting it on the bar

data.text:
If it were me I'd look for a mount that can also accommodate charging while riding. I use this charger while running ultras and don't have issues. https://www.amazon.com/Charger-Compatible-Charging-Accessory-Smartwatch/dp/B08C9VJ63T/ref=asc_df_B08C9VJ63T/?tag=hyprod-20&linkCode=df0&hvadid=564808018280&hvpos=&hvnetw=g&hvrand=4973992067833128935&hvpone=&hvptwo=&hvqmt=&hvdev=m&hvdvcmdl=&hvlocint=&hvlocphy=9017849&hvtargid=pla-1577256727823&psc=1

data.author: Mike McGinn

data.text: Yes I use a fenix 6. Check out the Edge 130. It‚Äôs pretty cheap but can pair up with the watch to give an extended display mounted on your bike while still wearing the watch.
data.author: Keith Jackson

data.text: Fenix 6x. Works like a charm.
data.author: Radha Krishna

data.text: For me that was same thinking - wanted one and went for Fenix 6 Pro. Not huge display, but works great and no issues with navigation if you install proper map. And had no issues with battery - went for a 2 day trip and after riding 6h a day I still had plenty of battery. Seems that 2 days are achievable even if you ride 10-12h a day. But will depend on your battery usage settings too.
data.author: Marcin Sowi≈Ñski

data.text: I've been using the phone with a Bluetooth handlebar speaker for several years. Work great and very easy on the battery.
data.author: David Butterly

data.text: I've got the Garmin forerunner 945. It's a brilliant watch and I use the navigation regularly for running and my bike rides. It's also a great fitness tracker and has improvement my fitness and workout routines. I have seen a few Fenix watches that friends own and due to it being metal it can scratch and dent quite quickly but the forerunner is plastic and in my opinion feels better and lasts longer.
data.author: Ian Roberts

data.text:
https://www.decathlon.co.uk/p/universal-bike-handlebar-watch-holder/_/R-p-145589 I've been using this for my suunto watch, works great
Universal Bike Handlebar Watch Holder
decathlon.co.uk
data.author: Alex Gillibrand

data.text: I guess it could work, but the map on my watch (fenix 6s pro) is super small and really only helpful for small hints as to where to go. However, check out the route functions. I used a preloaded route for a long distance hike last year and it gave me cues when to turn or when a turn was upcoming through alerts. This was more helpful to me than the map.
data.author: Erin Clay

data.text: I‚Äôm a theoretical through hiker. I like to read about it and it think it would be fun, but I‚Äôm not likely take the necessary time off the bike. BUT IF I DID, (I guess I‚Äôm a hypothetical through hiker now) I‚Äôd probably mount aero bars on my trekking poles and mount my Wahoo to that.
data.author: Justin M Short BA

data.text: Depends how good your eyesight is and how happy you are to have a tiny view of your route. I have a Fenix 5 Plus and bought it thinking I would do exactly what you describe but found it pretty useless TBH as there simply isn't enough detail to get a good idea where you are. Might work OK so long as you just follow a simple route and never deviate but using a dedicated bike computer is just SO much easier so I now have an Edge 1030 as well and use the Fenix for transmitting HR to the Edge plus for all non-bike sports without using the mapping.
data.author: Richard Young

data.text: Wokrs fine with a garmin Fenix 6x. So much battery life in comparaison of my wahoo elemnt
data.author: Tanguy Delval

data.text: Garmin GPS units are often found for cheap on Marketplace. I've picked up quite a few for pennies on the dollar.

data.text: Genius
data.author: Jan Aendenboom

data.text: That's exactly what I do. I use a bit of 22mm pipe insulation round the bars to hold it.
data.author: Pete Thomson

data.text: you can find much cheaper hand held garmin devices, to be mounted on the handlebars, the smart watch like fenix is quite expensive in comparison. I have both, the mounted hand held garmin is wit much bigger screen, at least to me far supirior for navigation
data.author: Dimitar Boradjiev

data.text: Garmin combined with a good iPhone has been a winning combination for me. I‚Äôm a regular rider and occasional Bikepacker.
data.author: Gilbert Vargas

data.text: 6x have been doing great. One thing you have take into an account, you have to charge it after each day. My battery was enough for 1.5 days long GPS usage days some days 14 hrs.
data.author: Krystian Gruba
J DL J DL

data.text: I use Wahoo fitness app on my phone to record and google maps to navigate. my bike has a phone mount on the stem of my bike
data.author: Jason Scott Rainville

data.text: I have a fenix6x solar. It is far superior to my garmin 820 as far as battery life. I take both on multiple day bikepacking trips. I mainly use the 820 for nav and have the watch for backup. The main downside to a watch is that it's hard to see/ use on the bike because it's small. That said I use it exclusively for mountain/fat biking because battery life is not affected by cold and it's easier to stop to look at the map when mountain biking if needed. On my road bike I use the 820 because it's easier to see. I also have a screen protector and case for my watch to keep it from scratching or damage. If you need it for multisport and can only get one I'd recommend a watch. They can track every sport. I use for biking, hiking, Paddleboard, snowshoe, and snowboarding. It has metrics and stats for everything.
data.author: Jason Kunkel

data.text: I‚Äôm about to finish riding the ‚Äòcape loop‚Äô on the Baja divide route in Baja Mexico. I camped and Airbnb‚Äôd it every few days for the last two weeks. I used my phone with my app of choice, wrapped in a battery case, and mounted it to my bars with an SP connect mount. I also brought an Anker power bank to provide power for the phone &case, lights, and AXS batteries. A typical day used 70% battery while navigating and was easily charged by the case or the power bank between available outlets.
data.author: Derek Meier

data.text: it works, BUT... I found myself leaning onto the bars to understand the small details. Requires a phone to replan / see the bigger picture (which is fine when off track). Navigating the menus can be a mess when you can't see the display well. The contrast (I use Fenix3 & 5) is very bad at low light conditions / overcast / shadows, unless you turn on the backlight which is battery consuming. After a couple of years handling the above, I switched to edge 830, huge improvement. Garmin rerouting still sucks and the unit often sends me to a false U-turn, but other than that it's great. So, if you just need an occasional reminder, that's fine. I wouldn't recommend for more elaborate navigation tasks...
data.author: Ethan Baratz

I just bought some better mount that works with Garmin edge mount

data.text: Yep I do and it's ace. Garmin do a rubber handlebar mount. Only rub is battery life...I get about 4 hours out of mine before it gives up...
data.author: Oliver Webb

data.text: I got started with GPS navigation, that exact way, using my Garmin 735 XT, and it works fine. But the relatively short battery life, and tiny screen, prompted me to get a bike specific Garmin eventually, and it's much better! If you're looking for something to hike with also, many long distance bikepackers actually use hiking Garmins, like the Etrex, mounted to their bars. A hiking Garmin will likely be my next gps purchase, since I also both backpack and bikepack. üëç
data.author: Marty Donaldson

data.text: I navigated Lands end to John oGroats in the uk 1000 miles all on bread crumb routes like this ‚Ä¶. It works üëçüèºüòÅ

data.text: Cell phone does it for me. And I opted for a InReach Mini for security and communication in the backcountry.

data.text: Display looks like on Garmin Edge 130 bike computer. Only difference that it's rounded not square. I do quite good with Edge 130. Takes about 50km to deeply understand how it works ana you're fine afterwards. Only once or twice a year I have to guess which of two closely located parallel roads to choose. That's becouse there's no map background on my device. Only GPX track.
data.author: Pawe≈Ç Wcis≈Ço

data.text: hey more people use Strava/phone gps than you‚Äôd believe. you dont need the fanciest gadgets, especially if it might hurt your savings.
data.author: Sean Healy

data.text: I wear a watch. Never considered remote mounting options. I feel naked without it. HRM and alti/barometer are the main functions I use it for.
data.author: Barkley Phan

data.text: Back up only
data.author: Yin Yang Adventures
Chris Knowles

data.text: Before getting in to bikepacking, I was pretty active with triathlon. After I upgraded to my Fenix3HR, I use/d the 910XT "head unit" on a quick release on my bike/s mainly as a bike computer - not for navigation unfortunately. Your concept is sound, just make sure you don't pull too tights on your wrist strap and cause a micro rip that results in a bigger problem or tech falling off mid ride.
data.author: Chris Pursel

data.text: I'd you're looking something to suit dual purpose a garmin fenix 6x plus, the 7x, or epix models would probably be best. Those models have larger screens which will be a bit large an the average sized wrist, but I feel will suffice on the bike. I have the 6x plus and it works for me. Would a dedicated GPS bike computer be better on the bike? Probably. But I also run and do other activities so I'm willing to make the compromise to save money and have the versatility.
data.author: Constantine Gogos

data.text: I have a Garmin Fenix 6X Pro with mapping capabilities. It would work, but the screen is a little small for biking and I would prefer not to use it. Plus, it is an expensive watch. I would keep it on my wrist rather than on the handlebars where you may not notice if it falls off.
data.author: Dave Walter

data.text: I use this for my Fenix 3, it easily goes on and off on the handlebars. Works very well.
data.author: Melissa Lewis Chapman

data.text: I have just come back from a 11-day ski tour in Norway where I used my 935 as a navigator for the duration of the tour. It was accurate and thrifty of battery usage. We did carry and refer to paper maps and a compass and carried a Garmin 66i as a back up.
data.author: Marcus Richardson

data.text: phone with external battery pack and komoot app.
data.author: Goran ZeeTso Zidariƒá

data.text: I do it the other way around, I use my garmin edge 130 on the bike and also handheld for hiking
data.author: Gareth Barker

data.text: I use a Suunto 9. Plan my route in OS Maps, export to Suunto and load to watch. Battery lasts all day, GPS is spot on. Carry my phone in pocket if the nav gets weird. Then go for a run the next day with the same device. Works for me.
data.author: Rob Berger

data.text: I use a Garmin fenix 6 Saphrie for navigation with hiking and mountainbiking, but never on the handlebar. The navigation is awesome, though.
data.author: Dany Marty

data.text: Totally possible!
data.author: Chris Dixon

data.text: I have a Garmin Instinct for 3 years now. It stays on my wrist... dont even bother putting it on the bike. It tracks my workouts and rides and its much less costly than the Fenix. It integrates well with RideWithGPS and I use that app on my phone for navigating and planning. Did 1500 miles of bikepacking last year (half of the GDMBR) using my phone for navigating and the Instinct for tracking
data.author: Steve Gold

data.text: Battery life is a killer. Watches weren‚Äôt made for this
data.author: Shawn Devlin

data.text: I use my iPhone for navigation, sport tracking, Pok√©moningüòÖüòÖ, photos, and everything else an iPhone can do.
data.author: Yue-Bei Teng

data.text: If you‚Äôve already got an Apple Watch then for just ¬£5 for the WorkOutdoors app you‚Äôll have masses of Watch navigation and route planning functionality. The app is brilliant for watch style navigation, and then checking back with your paired iPhone to get the bigger picture. Yo7 can also get proper UK OS mapping on your iPhone and Apple Watch.
data.author: Nigel Carrick

data.text: Having said that, I still prefer my Wahoo Roam for on bike navigation

data.text: I use my old Garmin Fenix 3 and it actually works ok. That said I also use an Etrex 22 so I‚Äôve never had to rely entirely on the watch. Depending where I was headed I‚Äôd be willing to try, particularly if you have a phone as backup.
